verses.text: Hard labor has been appointed for every human being, and a heavy yoke rests on the children of Adam, from the day they come forth from their mother’s womb until the day of their return to the mother of all.
verses.comment: This verse acknowledges the universal reality of toil and suffering that comes from humanity’s fall (Gen. 3:17–19). The phrase 'return to the mother of all' refers poetically to the grave (earth), connecting to biblical descriptions of death.

verses.text: Their thoughts and fears are of anxiety over what lies ahead, and the day of death troubles their reasoning and heart.
verses.comment: Here Sirach expresses the existential anxiety present in all, echoing the Psalms and Job. It points towards human longing for peace, and ultimately finds its answer in God's promise of rest.

verses.text: From the king in his glory, sitting even on his throne, to the poorest who is clothed in sackcloth and ashes,
verses.comment: No rank is exempt from life’s burdens; wisdom literature often shows the equality of all before death.

verses.text: Wrath, envy, unrest, turmoil, and dread—even life itself—all afflict them, and as they rest upon their beds, sleep brings only changed thoughts.
verses.comment: Vivid portrayal of inner turmoil; bridging human experience with biblical ideals of finding true peace in God alone.

verses.text: When one rises, he is disturbed by frightful thoughts, troubled by fear in his heart—like one who fled in battle.
verses.comment: Sleep gives no escape from anxiety; the sense of fleeing in battle is an image for the internal struggles faced by humanity.

verses.text: Hard labor, as if one is in danger of war, disturbs his thoughts; he cannot rest even in sleep, because his heart trembles with dread.
verses.comment: Sirach draws out the spiritual reality of restlessness—a consequence of the human condition—hinting toward the soul's need for true spiritual rest.

verses.text: With little or much, sleep is taken away from the eyes, and worry disturbs the soul when awake, as when in a dream one is pursued.
verses.comment: Dreams mirror inner anxieties; sleep rather than being restorative, can bring continued disturbance. Spiritual interpretation: enduring peace is found only in communion with God.

verses.text: Restless and unquiet are the nights of the rich, for they are troubled by cares and the abundance of their possessions.
verses.comment: Wealth does not shield from suffering or worry; it often multiplies them. Jesus’s parable of the rich fool (Luke 12:16–21) closely mirrors this wisdom.

verses.text: Small and great, master and servant—all alike—worry and anger, and distress and fear threaten them to death.
verses.comment: Recalls the equality of all people before death and judgment. Underlying idea: dependence on God alone is what delivers from these fears.

verses.text: Death and bloodshed, strife and sword, misfortune, famine, and affliction—all these were created for the wicked.
verses.comment: Divine justice is highlighted—misfortunes are depicted as consequences for wickedness, but not absolute condemnation; possibility of repentance remains.

verses.text: Evil comes from those who rejoice in malice and are eager for destruction, but the end of all things is the grave.
verses.comment: 'The grave' (Sheol) is the universal destination after death—a reminder both of mortality and the hope of resurrection found later in Scripture.

verses.text: All who come from the earth must return to the earth, just as all waters flow into the sea.
verses.comment: Sirach uses imagery of nature’s cycles to express the certainty of death and the unity of creation.

verses.text: All bribery and injustice will disappear, but faithfulness will endure forever.
verses.comment: Temporary gains through sin will not last; what endures is moral virtue and covenant faithfulness—a subtle encouragement to seek true righteousness.

verses.text: The riches of the unjust will dry up like a stream and fade away in thunder and rain, but righteousness flourishes like a green tree.
verses.comment: Imagery echoes Psalm 1 and highlights blessings for the righteous; this is both an ethical encouragement and spiritual reality.

verses.text: The offspring of sinners will not grow strong, and illegitimate roots will never take firm hold.
verses.comment: Incomplete translation: 'illegitimate' is used for 'impure seed,' signifying the ultimate futility of prosperity gained through unrighteous means.

verses.text: Even if they grow tall in branches for a time, they are rooted out and their foundation is blown away by the wind.
verses.comment: Resonates with the Psalms’ theme: temporary flourishing of the wicked is followed by destruction; a subtle call to perseverance in righteousness, not envy of worldly success.

verses.text: The stubborn branches are broken off; their fruit is rotten and cannot be eaten; it is good for nothing.
verses.comment: Jesus uses similar imagery in Matthew 7 concerning those who bear bad fruit; judgment and discernment are spiritual themes here.

verses.text: The works of the righteous are solid, but the wages of the wicked are wasted away like chaff.
verses.comment: Reminds of Psalm 1:4—chaff blown by the wind—contrasting the enduring legacy of virtue with the fleeting nature of evil.

verses.text: Favors and gifts lift up hearts, but better than both is righteous instruction; generosity is better than gold.
verses.comment: Instruction in virtue is more valuable than material charity; spiritual formation is seen as a priority, aligning with later teachings on works and grace.

verses.text: Charity is good when combined with discipline, and almsgiving is a blessing for those who practice it.
verses.comment: Almsgiving with proper intent is seen as spiritually fruitful—later found in Jesus’ teachings; subtly affirms the spiritual value of charitable works rooted in virtue rather than mere external acts.

verses.text: Better is the life of the poor under a shelter of planks, than rich feasts in another’s house.
verses.comment: True blessedness does not rely on earthly wealth. Spiritual interpretation: humble dwelling with God is greater than earthly abundance.

verses.text: With little or much, be satisfied; it is a miserable life to go from house to house.
verses.comment: Contentment is spiritual wisdom; echoes Jesus’ teaching to be free from anxiety about material needs (Matt. 6).

verses.text: To another’s table or couch, do not go boldly; for it is shameful for a sensible man.
verses.comment: Caution against presumption and lack of humility; biblical hospitality is valued, but respectful conduct is equally prized.

verses.text: Even if you are invited, do not behave greedily, and do not make yourself unpleasant by insistent demands.
verses.comment: Echoes Jesus’ parables on humility at feasts; spiritual fruit of humility and restraint is subtly emphasized as the 'greater way.'

verses.text: Honor is not fitting for one who is greedy, nor is a full life for one who lacks self-control.
verses.comment: The virtue of self-mastery is lauded; the subtly implied spiritual discipline elevates the soul.

verses.text: Work, prosperity, and discipline please the wise—but those who lack wisdom wander from house to house.
verses.comment: Industry and discipline are signs of wisdom; those who seek only pleasure are contrasted with stable, virtuous living.

verses.text: Much talk brings poverty to the mouth; always being bold brings rejection.
verses.comment: Self-restraint in speech is a biblical ideal (Prov. 10:19); spiritual fruit found in silence and contemplation subtly encouraged.

verses.text: Accept yourself with humility, and do not dishonor yourself by begging.
verses.comment: Sirach commends acceptance and humility rather than seeking to gain by begging; inward disposition is as important as outward deeds.

verses.text: It is better to work and have enough than to depend on the generosity of others, for the life of one who looks to the table of others is not a life worth living.
verses.comment: Principle of honest labor is encouraged, reflecting biblical wisdom. Spiritual meaning: dignity in bearing one’s cross and daily work.

verses.text: With a shameless mouth you may ask, but inside is a burning heart. The beggar’s voice rejoices at someone’s generosity, but his feelings are hidden.
verses.comment: Hidden suffering of the poor is recognized; call to compassionate charity echoes throughout scripture. The deeper spiritual love shown in giving with a right heart is implied.
